question: Will the DC cherry trees reach peak bloom on or before March 27 in 2025?
reasoning:
Based on the gathered evidence, here are the key points:

1. The National Park Service and other sources have forecasted that the peak bloom for the DC cherry blossoms in 2025 is expected to occur between March 28 and 31. This forecast was made based on current weather conditions and historical data.

2. As of March 24, 2025, the cherry blossoms have reached the "Peduncle Elongation" stage, and there have been cooler temperatures and persistent light rain, which are slowing down the blooming process.

3. Historically, peak bloom has occurred as early as March 15 and as late as April 18, but the most common period is between the last week of March and the first week of April.

4. The forecasted peak bloom dates (March 28-31) are after the resolution date of March 27, 2025, which means it is unlikely for the peak bloom to occur on or before March 27.

Given these points, the probability that the DC cherry trees will reach peak bloom on or before March 27, 2025, is low.

FINAL PROBABILITY: 0.1

Peak Bloom March 28-31

**Follow Our Updates on Social Media**

**Facebook**: [www.facebook.com/NationalMallNPS](https://www.facebook.com/NationalMallNPS/)

#BloomWatch

#CherryBlossomDC

Peak Bloom & Blooming Period

**When is peak bloom?**

The **peak bloom date** is defined as the day when **70%** of the Yoshino Cherry (*Prunus x yedoensis*) blossoms are open. Peak bloom varies annually depending on weather conditions. The most likely time to reach peak bloom is between the last week of March and the first week of April. Extraordinary warm or cool temperatures have resulted in peak bloom as early as March 15 (1990) and as late as April 18 (1958).


**How long is peak bloom? **

The Yoshino trees typically bloom for a period of **several days**. The length of the blooming period depends on weather conditions. Cool, calm weather can extend the length of the bloom, and a rainy, windy day can bring an abrupt end to the ephemeral blossoms. A late frost can prevent the trees from blooming at all.


**Predicting the bloom.**

Forecasting peak bloom is almost impossible more than **10 days in advance**. The cherry trees' blossom development is dependent on weather conditions. National Park Service horticulturists monitor bud development and report the status of the blossoms.

### Join us for Blossoms Food Fun Culture Entertainment Events More in 2024

## MAKE YOUR FESTIVAL PLANS

**PEAK BLOOM predicted DATES: MARCH 28 – 31**

On February 27, 2025, the National Park Service announced predicted peak bloom dates. We encourage you to check them out on our #BloomCam if you can’t visit the Tidal Basin.

Peak bloom is when 70% of the iconic cherry blossoms open on the Yoshino cherry trees around the Tidal Basin in Washington, DC. The full blooming period lasts from several days to up to two weeks, depending on weather conditions.

While peak bloom has occurred the blossoms are still blooming at the Tidal Basin. While the blooming period is difficult to predict more than ten days in advance, the Festival has so much to offer throughout a City in Bloom no matter when the blossoms bloom.








On March 17, 2024, the National Park Service announced that the trees have **PEAK BLOOM**! The blossoms are still blooming and we encourage you to check them out on our #BloomCam if you can’t visit the Tidal Basin.

Peak bloom is when 70% of the iconic cherry blossoms open on the Yoshino cherry trees around the Tidal Basin in Washington, DC. The full blooming period lasts from several days to up to two weeks, depending on weather conditions.

### WATCH THE BLOSSOMS LIVE

# #BloomCam

**#BloomCam**, brought to you by the Trust for the National Mall, in partnership with the National Park Service and Earthcam, is a 24/7, live, real-time view of the cherry trees lining the Tidal Basin, one of the most popular and iconic sites in Washington, DC. Positioned on the Salamander Washington DC rooftop, [#BloomCam](https://nationalmall.org/bloomcam) offers year-round views of the cherry trees and their seasonal changes to viewers worldwide and is highlighted here during Bloom Watch as we await the peak blooms.

## Special Thanks to EarthCam for their support in making the #BloomCam possible!

## National Park Service

messages.content:
Based on the following question, analyze it carefully and provide your probability estimate.

Question: Will the DC cherry trees reach peak bloom on or before March 27 in 2025?
Background: [In 1912](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Cherry_Blossom_Festival#Early_initiatives), the mayor of Tokyo sent 3,020 cherry trees as a symbol of friendship between Japan and the United States. The trees were largely planted around the Tidal Basin near the Jefferson Memorial. Over time, some of the original trees have died, but have been replaced or propagated, to reach a total of about [3,800 trees](https://www.nps.gov/subjects/cherryblossom/types-of-trees.htm) as of 2025.

Every year since 1927, the National Cherry Blossom Festival commemorates this gift with a celebration that has grown from a simple ceremony into a major cultural event drawing visitors from around the world to watch the cherries bloom, signalling the arrival of spring.

The timing of the bloom varies each year, depending on weather conditions, and is carefully tracked by the National Park Service (NPS). Peak bloom is [defined](https://www.nps.gov/subjects/cherryblossom/bloom-watch.htm) as the day when 70% of the [Yoshino cherry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prunus_%C3%97_yedoensis) blossoms are open - the Yoshino variety being the most common in the Tidal Basin. It usually happens in the last week of March or the first week of April, but extreme temperatures have resulted in peaks as early as March 15 (1990) and as late as April 18 (1958).

As of the beginning of March, peak bloom is forecasted to take place between March 28 and 31. Data for past blooms can be found [here](https://www.nps.gov/subjects/cherryblossom/bloom-watch.htm).
Resolution criteria: This question will resolve as YES if the National Park Service (NPS) announces that the 2025 Peak Bloom date occurred on or before March 27, 2025. Otherwise, it will resolve as NO.
Fine print: If credible sources point to the peak bloom having taken place, but NPS does not officially announce a date, this question will resolve as AMBIGUOUS.

You may reason through the problem, but you MUST end your response with:
FINAL PROBABILITY: [your decimal number between 0 and 1]

Peak Bloom March 28-31

**Follow Our Updates on Social Media**

**Facebook**: [www.facebook.com/NationalMallNPS](https://www.facebook.com/NationalMallNPS/)

**Twitter**: [twitter.com/NationalMallNPS](https://twitter.com/NationalMallNPS)

**Instagram**: [instagram.com/NationalMallNPS](https://www.instagram.com/nationalmallnps/)

#BloomWatch

#CherryBlossomDC

Peak Bloom & Blooming Period

**When is peak bloom?**

The **peak bloom date** is defined as the day when **70%** of the Yoshino Cherry (*Prunus x yedoensis*) blossoms are open. Peak bloom varies annually depending on weather conditions. The most likely time to reach peak bloom is between the last week of March and the first week of April. Extraordinary warm or cool temperatures have resulted in peak bloom as early as March 15 (1990) and as late as April 18 (1958).


**How long is peak bloom? **

The Yoshino trees typically bloom for a period of **several days**. The length of the blooming period depends on weather conditions. Cool, calm weather can extend the length of the bloom, and a rainy, windy day can bring an abrupt end to the ephemeral blossoms. A late frost can prevent the trees from blooming at all.


**Predicting the bloom.**

Forecasting peak bloom is almost impossible more than **10 days in advance**. The cherry trees' blossom development is dependent on weather conditions. National Park Service horticulturists monitor bud development and report the status of the blossoms.

The most likely time to reach peak bloom is between the last week of March and the first week of April. Extraordinary warm or cool temperatures have resulted in peak bloom as early as March 15 (1990) and as late as April 18 (1958).


**How long is peak bloom? **

The Yoshino trees typically bloom for a period of **several days**. The length of the blooming period depends on weather conditions. Cool, calm weather can extend the length of the bloom, and a rainy, windy day can bring an abrupt end to the ephemeral blossoms. A late frost can prevent the trees from blooming at all.


**Predicting the bloom.**

Forecasting peak bloom is almost impossible more than **10 days in advance**. The cherry trees' blossom development is dependent on weather conditions. National Park Service horticulturists monitor bud development and report the status of the blossoms.

Based on the gathered evidence, here are the key points:

1. The National Park Service and other sources have forecasted that the peak bloom for the DC cherry blossoms in 2025 is expected to occur between March 28 and 31. This forecast was made based on current weather conditions and historical data.

2. As of March 24, 2025, the cherry blossoms have reached the "Peduncle Elongation" stage, and there have been cooler temperatures and persistent light rain, which are slowing down the blooming process.

3. Historically, peak bloom has occurred as early as March 15 and as late as April 18, but the most common period is between the last week of March and the first week of April.

4. The forecasted peak bloom dates (March 28-31) are after the resolution date of March 27, 2025, which means it is unlikely for the peak bloom to occur on or before March 27.

Given these points, the probability that the DC cherry trees will reach peak bloom on or before March 27, 2025, is low.

FINAL PROBABILITY: 0.1
